information_requirement: Is the adversary impacting availability through application or system exploitation?

evidence.description: Network traffic matching known signatures for denial-of-service (DoS) exploits or tools targeting specific applications or systems.
evidence.action: Deploy and monitor Zeek signature sets (or an equivalent IDS correlated with Zeek logs) that identify known DoS attack patterns (e.g., Slowloris, RUDY, specific CVE exploit payloads). Monitor Zeek's notice.log for alerts generated by these signatures, such as 'Scan::Port_Scan' or custom DoS-related notices. Correlate signature hits with observed service degradation or crash events (Windows Event ID 1000/1001) on the targeted system by joining network and host logs on timestamp and destination IP.

evidence.description: Execution of processes or processing of files exhibiting known patterns of resource exhaustion, such as fork bombs or high-compression-ratio files ('zip bombs').
evidence.action: Monitor process creation events (Windows Event ID 4688) for patterns of rapid, recursive process creation from a single parent, indicative of a fork bomb. Analyze Zeek files.log for files with exceptionally high compression ratios or magic numbers associated with crash-inducing files. Use correlation analysis to link the processing of a suspicious file or the execution of a suspicious process with a subsequent application or system crash (Windows Event ID 1000/1001) on the same host.

evidence.description: A rapid succession of application or system error events indicating resource exhaustion (e.g., out of memory, handle exhaustion) immediately preceding a system crash or restart.
evidence.action: Monitor for specific resource exhaustion events (like Windows Event ID 2004, 'Resource-Exhaustion-Detector') or application error messages within Event ID 1000 that explicitly mention memory, handles, or other critical resources. Use time series analysis to detect a cluster or statistically significant increase in these specific errors occurring shortly before a system becomes unresponsive or restarts (logged by Windows Event ID 6005/6006). Correlate these error clusters with specific running applications or newly created processes (from Windows Event ID 4688) to pinpoint the cause.

evidence.description: A sudden and sustained spike in network traffic volume, connection rate, or request complexity from one or more sources targeting a specific service, leading to its unavailability.
evidence.action: Establish a dynamic baseline of normal network traffic patterns (e.g., connections/sec, bandwidth, request complexity, source IP entropy) for critical public-facing services using historical Zeek conn.log and http.log data. Employ time series analysis (e.g., ARIMA, Holt-Winters) to detect statistically significant deviations from this baseline. Analyze the distribution of source IPs; a sudden drop in entropy (traffic from one or few sources) or a massive increase (DDoS) are both indicators. Use box-plots on connection rates per source IP to identify aggressive outliers. Correlate traffic anomalies with application performance degradation or crash events.

evidence.description: A statistically significant increase in the rate of application or system crashes on one or more systems, without an obvious link to a recent, authorized patching or configuration change.
evidence.action: Create a baseline for the normal frequency of application crashes (Event ID 1000/1001) and system restarts (Event ID 6005/6006) for groups of similar assets (e.g., web servers, domain controllers). Continuously monitor for any system or group of systems exceeding a defined threshold (e.g., mean + 3 standard deviations of the crash rate). Use linear regression or correlation analysis to rule out benign causes by checking for correlation with known maintenance windows or software deployment times. Investigate unexplained spikes in instability as potential impact events.
